climbs.name: Yegg
climbs.fa: Mason Frichette and Craig Lightburn,  late 70s

content.description:
This is the farthest left crack climb on the Third Band. There is a medium-size tree right next to it. It starts as a finger crack and opens up to a hand crack. The rock at the start is particularly sharp.

A note about the rating: Gillett writes in his guidebook to the canyon "the opening moves are a little harder than 5.9, but it's simple enough to cheat by using a foothold in the cedar [tree]". We didn't use the tree and the proposed rating reflects that. A larger wingspan than mine (6'0") may make it easier than what I proposed.
content.protection: Standard rack from a #0.4 to #3 Camalot. There's a cold-shut at the top of the crack and a single bolt to its left. I belayed at the bolt and backed it up with a #3 Camalot.
content.location:
This is on a block called the Egg that can be seen from the road. It's the furthest left block on the Third Band. This will probably be the first route that you encounter when approaching the Third Band.

Descend by walking off the backside. Exit climber's left to get back to the base.

climbs.name: If You Don't Leave Me, I'll Find Someone Who Will

content.description: This route ascends a finger- and hand-crack to a roof. Going straight up through the roof keeps the grade at 9 while traversing right at the obvious flake to the next crack is mid-10 (flared jams; small feet; there's a perfect #0.75 Camalot to protect the traverse right).
content.protection: Standard rack; emphasize smaller cams and small to medium stoppers. Hand-size cams are useful for the belay.
content.location:
This route is on the Top 40 Wall (see Third Band overview photo for the location). One can access this by continuing right from Space Balls to a rappel anchor atop Flying Fish. Rappel down and you'll be at the left margin of the Top 40 Wall.

The descent is a third-class scramble to the climber's right.

climbs.name: If You Can’t Live Without Me, Why Aren’t You Dead Yet?

content.description: Begin with low angle crack climbing past a few shrubs to a stem box-like top section with two large hand cracks. Set up a belay on a tree with rap tat and rings.
content.location:
It is 20’ right of ’

If You Don’t Leave Me

....’

climbs.name: How Can I Miss You If You Won't Go Away?
climbs.fa: FFA: Bernard Gillett and Paul Bodnar, 2004

content.description:
This is on the Top 40 Wall. To the right of If You Won't Leave Me ..., you'll find two cracks. This is the right of the two. Climb a flaring cracking reminiscent of Lumpy to a ledge. Jog right a bit and climb the obvious finger crack to a flake.

An interesting variation is to climb the hand- and fist-crack to the right of the finger crack on the upper portion of the route (bumps the grade up to 8+ or so; big fun on this one). Bring an extra #3 Camalot or equivalent for this variation.
content.protection: A standard rack up to a #4 Camalot. Build your own belay anchor at the top.
content.location: See the photo for the start. To descend, head climber's left to a large tree with slings. Make a single rappel (about 95 feet) back down to the base of the wall.

climbs.name: Hacky Sack
climbs.fa: FFA: Bernard Gillett and Paul Bodnar, 2003

content.description:
This route is on the block called Space Balls. This feature can be seen from the road and in general from most of the approach.

It starts with a slot to a shelf and then goes up a right-facing corner to the top.
content.protection: Standard rack. There are several bolts at the top of Space Balls but they are not set up for a rappel.
content.location: This is on the right side of Space Balls on the Third Band. You'll likely be approaching from the Egg. There is one exposed third-class move to get to the base of this route. Look for the prominent slot. Descend by scrambling climber's left back to a notch between the Egg and this formation.

content.description: This climb is a wide variety pack. Start with about 30 feet of #6 Camalot in a corner.  Don't worry, you don't need multiple #6s as there are gear opportunities in a seam out right as well as deeper in the crack. Finish this section, and work up into a tight full body chimney. This section doesn't get much pro but is very secure and goes at 5.7. The exit moves can be protected. Finish on a beautiful, wide hands/#3 Camalot crack to a ledge, and build a belay.
content.protection: A standard rack with a #6. Maybe throw in an extra #3.
content.location: This is on the far right side of the Third Band. It is probably best to approach from the left via Third Class scrambling. It is hard to see the climb from directly below; however, the 5.10 corner crack is very obvious, and this line is just to the right of that.

content.description: Start below the aid route, climb up to a right-angling hand crack, mantel to a ledge (9), and climb the obvious crack off the ledge (10-) to good hand jams and the top of the Flying Fish Buttress. Build an anchor to the right, and rap off bolts at the top of aid line.
content.protection: A standard rack, a #4 is nice, and a #6 gets in the way.
content.location:
On the Flying Fish Buttress east along third band from Space Balls, this ascends the obvious crack that faces east. The top of the crack is noticeable if you look west from base of "

How Can I Miss You If You Won't Go Away?

"

pathTokens: South Fork of St. Vrain Canyon
